data:
In this guide, we will show you how to locally install and set up the Plow CLI,
and how to take common actions (e.g. publishing a package) with it.

Plow is a package manager for ontologies, bringing established practices from software engineering
into the world of ontology engineering. It similar to programming language package manager such as
npm and cargo.Plow consists of a few distinct core components:
the official registry
the website for the official registry
the Command Line Interface (CLI)

The official registry is a database of packages (called fields in Plow) that is controlled via a
JSON API. It allows anyone to publish packages for public or private consumption for any knowledge
domain.The registry website allows for discovery of packages via search,
categories and keywords. It also provides an overview of relevant metadata (ontology project website,
license, dependencies, etc.) for all versions of all packages.The CLI allows for interacting with the registry from the terminal. It allows for e.g. publishing new
fields, resolving dependencies of an ontology project and/or opening an ontology with dependencies in Protege.

data.installing-rust-toolchain#Installing Rus:
To install the Plow CLI, currently an installation of a recent version of the Rust language toolchain
is required.
To provide an easier setup process that doesn't require installing the Rust toolchain, we are working on providing pre-built binaries of the CLI.
data.installing-the-plow-cli-binary#Installin:
To install the Plow CLI via cargo, you can run in a terminal:
cargo install plow_cli
After the installation is finished, you can verify that the binary is available via:
plow --help
data.login-to-public-registry#Login to public:
In order to take certain actions with the Plow CLI (e.g. publishing a package)
or to have access to private packages that have been shared with your Plow registry
account, you have to authenticate your installation of the CLI.
Log in (or create an account) under registry.field33.com
In your account settings create a new User Token, and copy it to your clipboard
In a terminal run (substituting [USER_TOKEN] with the token from your clipboard):
plow login [USER_TOKEN]
